image.altText: A two-storey health centre in suburban Adelaide.

items.synopsis: The South Australian doctors' union says women seeking pregnancy terminations will continue to be consulted in a mouldy and dilapidated building for up to three months.

image.altText: A woman is choosing fruits at supermarket.

items.synopsis: Consumer prices rose 1.2 per cent in the September quarter, slightly above economist forecasts and increasing the risks of another Reserve Bank interest rate rise.

title.children: Inflation stronger than expected and now has banks and traders pricing in a November rate rise

items.synopsis: The ASX has opened higher at the start of tradeÂ after US corporate earnings generally beat expectations, while the ABS says fuel, electricity and rents influenced a 1.2 per cent rise in inflation. Follow live.

title.children: ASX opens higher, ABS says higher fuel prices behind jump in inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're after another hot take on inflation, you're in the right place. My colleague, senior business correspondent Peter Ryan told The World Today that there's no two ways about it â€” these inflation numbers will be a big concern for the RBA board. "That's because while the pace of inflation seems to be slowing, it's not slowing fast enough â€” it's still higher than expected at 5.4% over the year and lower than 6% in the last quarter â€” but still well above the 2 to 3% target where the RBA eventually wants it," he said. If you've got a spare four minutes, you can listen to his full analysis below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ðŸŽ§ Why the RBA is more concerned with the pace of inflation than the current rate

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today's inflation figures were enough for ANZ to shift its thinking on the RBA's rates meeting next month, saying it now expects the cash rate to increase by 0.25 percentage points, taking the official rate to 4.35%. Given the RBA's "hawkish rhetoric over the past two weeks" and the "uncomfortably high" September quarter inflation data, ANZ says it's expecting the cash rate to reach its highest level since November 2011 â€” but noted the hike wasn't certain. "The RBA has also highlighted risks of inflation expectations becoming embedded given ongoing shocks to energy prices, with consumersâ€™ inflation expectations typically being quite responsive to petrol prices," ANZ's head of economics Adam Boyton wrote. "While an additional interest rate increase will put further pressure on already strained finances across some households, the RBAâ€™s most recent Financial Stability Review observed that households and businesses in Australia have, overall, coped reasonably well with the [4 percentage point] cash rate hikes so far. "Having said that, a rate hike in November is not certain. Major inputs into the RBAâ€™s longer-term inflation forecast are unlikely to have changed materially. "Wages growth has generally undershot the RBA's expectations over this cycle, while the likely increase in productivity in Q3 should provide some comfort to the Bank that a reversion to the pre-COVID trend is plausible. That is, the longer-term inflation forecasts could well be unaffected by today's data. "As a result, a decision to increase rates in November could well be a response to the risk that inflation might not return to target within a reasonable timeframe. A risk highlighted by the resilience of inflation in the [September inflation data]."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ expects RBA to increase cash rate to 4.35pc in November

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a positive start to Wednesday trade for the ASX, but its early morning gains have taken a substantial hit in the wake of inflation data coming in higher than economists had expected. As of 12:10pm AEDT, the ASX 200 is down -0.2% to 6,844 points. Investors are now weighing up the possibility of a November rate hike by the RBA, with the market currently forecasting a 60.6% chance of an increase next month. Before the inflation data was released, that forecasted rate hike probability was sitting at just 35%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX loses ground after inflation figures exceed expectations

children.content: It was a positive start to Wednesday trade for the ASX, but its early morning gains have taken a substantial hit in the wake of inflation data coming in higher than economists had expected.
As of 12:10pm AEDT, the ASX 200 is down
-0.2% to 6,844 points
Investors are now weighing up the possibility of a November rate hike by the RBA, with the
market currently forecasting a 60.6% chance of an increase
next month.
Before the inflation data was released, that forecasted rate hike probability was sitting at just 35%.
